abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation Support
            Project for Nepal are as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the projects included: donors need to
            work together more effectively, with each working to their
            comparative advantage, the aim being to achieve a harmonized
            sector-wide approach that avoids duplication and
            contradictions. In Nepal this assessment found while it made
            sense for donors' projects to be geographically
            differentiated this was at the expense of sector-wide
            coordination and mutual learning. Do not lose sight of
            project beneficiaries. Too much attention to water resource
            policy and management deflected attention from the need to
            reform public sector management of large-scale irrigation
            projects and improve service delivery. As a result the
            longer-term sustainability of the public irrigation
            subsector and farmers' livelihoods dependent on it are
            at high risk in Nepal. Non-governmental organizations (NGOs)
            are generally better at working with farmers to increase the
            productivity of small-scale farmer-managed irrigation
            systems. The project clearly demonstrated that partnership
            with NGOs in Nepal enabled agricultural productivity
            improvements in remote locations where the poorest rural
            communities are located. Greater attention should be given
            to monitoring and evaluation to ensure informed policy
            making and decision making. In Nepal the scope of data
            collection and storage of data on agricultural input and
            output performance information significantly contracted
            during the transition from public to private service provision.

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Irrigation Sector
            Project for Nepal were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate the implementation experience of Nepal
            Irrigation Sector Project (NISP) has shown that in Nepal it
            is not administratively advisable to include a stand-alone
            investment, such as Sunsari Morang Irrigation Project
            (SMIP), as part of a sector program. For complex design
            projects, financial management arrangements at least, have
            to be made simple during the design stage. The failure of
            the Department of Agriculture/Agricultural Research and
            Extension Project (DOA/AREP) to deliver improved
            agricultural extension services to Farmer-Managed Irrigation
            Scheme (FMIS) supported under NISP, has clearly demonstrated
            the risks associated with relying on separate initiatives to
            provide services needed for component implementation,
            especially where close coordination and proper integration
            between the components are needed. Considerable difficulties
            remain with regards to the structure and operation of WUA on
            publicly managed schemes like SMIP. The identification and
            screening of FMIS for improvement and rehabilitation is a
            difficult process that requires the use of an objective
            transparent process, such as those developed under the
            project. FMIS canals in the hills have been found vulnerable
            to frequent natural disasters. The experience of M&E in
            SMIP compared to the FMIS sub-component demonstrated that it
            is not possible to carry out effective M&E unless clear
            indications are provided as to how it will be funded, and
            how it will be undertaken. In sector-wide projects like NISP
            it is very important that the position of Project
            Coordinator is filled by a senior experienced officer, and
            that he or she is kept in post for as long as possible. The
            full benefit from improvement and rehabilitation of FMIS is
            only achieved when the investment made includes the
            provision of technical advice on agriculture and water
            management, as well as the construction of civil works.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Irrigation Sector Project will
            assist the Government in planning and utilizing its water
            resources in a harmonized, effective and sustainable manner.
            The project has three components:  a) Finalization of a
            Comprehensive Water Resources Strategy and formulation of a
            Consolidated Water Policy;  b) Irrigation sector improvement
            and development, it includes improvement of productivity and
            sustainability of irrigation systems on 59,600 ha in
            accordance of HMGN s Irrigation Policy (IP); and  c)
            Institutional strengthening, this component will support the
            strengthening of the implementing agencies to ensure proper
            implementation of components A and B, and strengthening the
            Government's technical and institutional capacity in
            water data collection, planning and management of irrigated agriculture.
